nodes.bodyText: Is getting Checks per country not going to be supported moving forward? // Is it depended on the being able to access the persisted RDD?

I'm not sure I exactly follow the question, but all this has to do with creating job labels for the Spark UI. In order to run and label each country as a different job in spark this is persisting the RDD, calling count (just to force execution), and then unioning the results to get everything into one stream. So checks are fully by country.

I believe making a new one of these WILL work for every atlas fetcher, but if you can make it a transient static lazy initialized I believe that will mean each JVM working in the spark cluster will use its own, which may allow for optimizations.
The caches are using a global namespace, so I think this should already effectively be one cache store per machine in the cluster.
These two variables can be local variables.
I am not sure why I made these like this. I think it might be best to make them static variable, as apposed to local. Any thoughts?
We can define this String literal "ItemId" in GeoJsonUtils class!!

     }
 
     /**
-     * Get the atlas ids from an array of features.
+     * Get the unique ids for a flag. Fall back to getting the atlas ids from the features for
+     * reverse compatibility.
      *
-     * @param features
-     *            a {@link JsonArray} of features
+     * @param flagJson
+     *            a {@link JsonObject} of a flag
      * @return a {@link Set} of {@link String} ids
      */
-    private Set<String> getAtlasIdentifiers(final JsonArray features)
+    private Set<String> getIdentifiers(final JsonObject flagJson)
     {
-        return Iterables.stream(features)
-                .filter(object -> object.getAsJsonObject().get(PROPERTIES).getAsJsonObject()
-                        .has(IDENTIFIER))
-                .map(object -> object.getAsJsonObject().get(PROPERTIES).getAsJsonObject()
-                        .get(IDENTIFIER).getAsString())
-                .collectToSet();
+        final JsonObject flagProperties = flagJson.get(PROPERTIES).getAsJsonObject();
+        return flagProperties.has(IDENTIFIERS)
+                ? Iterables.stream(flagProperties.get(IDENTIFIERS).getAsJsonArray())
+                        .map(JsonElement::getAsString).collectToSet()
+                : Iterables.stream(flagJson.get(FEATURES).getAsJsonArray()).filter(object -> object
+                        .getAsJsonObject().get(PROPERTIES).getAsJsonObject().has(IDENTIFIER)
+                        || object.getAsJsonObject().get(PROPERTIES).getAsJsonObject().has("ItemId"))

nodes.bodyText: This is a bit of a funny one in that it is not a standard geojson key. It should probably be defined as a public constant somewhere in the output event classes. There are a bunch of similar items in the event classes that could use a refactor. It would probably be best to have a separate PR to update all of them.

nodes.bodyText: Will POOL_DURATION_BEFORE_KILL value remains the same? Also, may I know if it is a random assigned value or any estimated value.
This is a constant value of 300 seconds. It configures the Pool to kill any check that takes longer then that time to run.
300 minutes, right?
Sorry, yes this is minutes.
Are you able to import the event package from atlas, or is there a conflicting package issue ?
I'm able to import, not sure why that ended up like that. I will fix that.
Is toJsonTree converting the ids to an array? If so, what's the advantage of using an array vs string?

Yes it is converting it to a json array.
I think there are a few advantages. It makes it easier to read and prettify when in json format. There is no issue with trying to deal with gigantic unbroken strings.  A lot of languages have no problem loading a json array into a native collection format, so they can then easily use the ids in a separated (search) or combined (id) manor.
That said, it would probably work just about as well to have his as a csv string. For an example of how it is currently used by downstream tools look at the changes to the geojson and log diff tools in this PR.
Unrelated to you changes but.. whats the purpose of the configJson switch?
It so you could pass the contents of a configuration file directly as json, instead of requiring the file.
How is this used?
It is used to filter out bad unique ids created from flagged points that are not from atlas entities.
multi -> multiAtlas
🙏 Thanks for adding this!
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,58 @@
+# Sharded Atlas Checks

nodes.bodyText: Remove "this" keyword as COUNTRY_WHITELIST_TEMPLATE is a static variable.
Same as my previous comment.
What are these warnings?
I'm not sure what rawtypes is for, but was already there. unchecked is for unchecked casts, that are happening when getting values from the command map.
Why is this deprecated?
That is a carryover from @jklamer's original PR. My assumption, and why I left it, is that it would be better to use the 'input' switch from the SparkJob base class.
nit: missing serialVersionUID
I don't think you need this for an abstract class.

I think you still need the serial number if IntegrityChecksCommandArguments has any subclasses, and we plan on reading/writing objects of those classes somewhere. But since I don't think we're doing that it should be fine for now
See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/893259/should-an-abstract-class-have-a-serialversionuid
Interesting! I don't foresee a need to serialize an entire spark job, but as the class is serializable I will add this.
Couldn't we import this?

nodes.bodyText: Why are these changes?
Changing to use the classes in atlas, instead of replicating them in atlas checks.
nit: Could we do a static import here?
It would not be static, as Atlas is a class. I could import the class, but that seems excessive for just a doc reference.
What are these changes?
Automatic code rearrangement.
If this condition fails we could log that we're skipping the file. Could be useful for debugging in case a shard file has a bad name and doesn't get loaded
I agree, I have added that.
Since we're reading in the raw country string are we handling invalid country strings?
Country strings are only invalid if they don't have corresponding files. If that is the case then that is handled by the block on line 194.
What if we load shards for countries that are given in the configuration but have no checks in countryChecks?
I suppose this could happen if we specify a country in the config and a checkFilter but the checks are disabled in that country, so we'd want to exit
There is a check for this on line 171.
Wondering how useful it'd be to have a configurable DynamicAtlasPolicy, or one defined in a file

This is definitely something I want to have eventually. That may be part of the solution for dealing with large relations. For now I think it is fine to have it hard coded while that solution is architected.

One of @seancoulter's comments made me realize that there are a lot of soft failures used in the start method to short circuit execution of the new spark job. These were added in the original PR, so I had just left them alone. I am now wondering if it might be better to throw exceptions, to make it more evident why the job did not do anything. Does anyone have an opinion on this?
